items.title: Syrian Refugees Strain Resources in Jordan
items.abstract: Despite plans by aid organizations to help at least 50,000 urban refugees, a large number will be left out because of the rising numbers of Syrians fleeing across the border each day.
keywords: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )

items.title: City Names 17 Schools Slated to Close
items.abstract: New York City education officials released the first round of names of schools to be shut down, with more names coming on Tuesday.
keywords: High School of Graphic Communication Arts

items.title: Record Number of Misconduct Complaints Are Made Against City School Employees
items.abstract: The office of the Special Commissioner of Investigation handled 4,173 complaints, more than double the amount received during the first year of the Bloomberg administration.

items.title: New York City to Restrict Prescription Painkillers in Public Hospitals’ Emergency Rooms
items.abstract: In an effort to crack down on drug abuse, most patients at the 11 hospitals will no longer be able to get more than three days’ worth of narcotic painkillers like Vicodin and Percocet.

items.title: In Rural Minnesota, a 70-Acre Lab for Sustainable Living
items.abstract: Imagine a house that can go without heating for two days in a bitterly cold winter. Or a greenhouse with what may be the largest hot-air solar panel array in North America.

items.title: Man Wrongly Convicted in ’97 Brooklyn Killing Settles With City and State
items.abstract: Roger Logan, who spent 17 years in prison for a fatal shooting, has reached agreements of $3.75 million from New York City and $2.975 million from New York State.

items.title: De Blasio to Announce New System Dedicated to Addressing Gun Crime in New York City
items.abstract: Starting this month, people charged with the possession of a firearm in the city will be sent to State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, which will preside over gun arrest cases.

items.title: As Cuomo Acts on Homeless Problem, New York City Blames State Cuts
items.abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is only one player in addressing the issue in the city, but decisions his administration has made have left the city shouldering more of the burden.

items.title: Bowie Tribute Concert to Have a Second Night, at Radio City
items.abstract: The Carnegie Hall concert honoring David Bowie on March 31 will be joined by a second tribute show, at Radio City Music Hall on April 1.

items.title: City’s Delayed Traffic Study to Guide Regulation of Uber Vehicles
items.abstract: The study, which was originally due at the end of November, aimed to assess the ride-hailing service’s effects on traffic congestion in Manhattan.

items.title: In High-Tech Cities, No More Potholes, but What About Privacy?
items.abstract: Cities, including some far from the coasts, are vying to use technology to guide services. But the race toward “smart cities” is raising privacy worries.

items.title: Bright Spot for N.Y.’s Struggling Schools: Pre-K
items.abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s broader plan for public schools has been disappointing, but his universal pre-K initiative shows steady improvement.

items.title: This Is Probably the Best Bath in New York City
items.abstract: For $7,000, you too can bathe like a very wealthy person.

items.title: Judge Blocks New York City Law Aimed at Curbing Airbnb Rentals
items.abstract: The law was intended to prevent apartments from being used as illegal hotels. The decision could aid home-sharing services’ fights in other cities.

items.title: New York City’s Poor Were Promised Half-Priced MetroCards. They’re Still Waiting.
items.abstract: New York City was scheduled to start a discount fare program for low-income riders on Jan. 1. But the rollout has been a bit of a mess.
keywords: Community Service Society of New York

items.title: Eric Adams Takes Office as New York City’s 110th Mayor at a Perilous Moment
items.abstract: Eric Adams, the city’s second Black mayor, faces difficult decisions over how to lead New York City through the next wave of the pandemic.

items.title: A New Mayor and a New Relationship Between City Hall and Albany
items.abstract: Unlike their feuding predecessors, Mayor Eric Adams and Gov. Kathy Hochul appear to be getting along. They have their reasons.

items.title: City Schools Are ‘Staying Open,’ Mayor Eric Adams Says
items.abstract: But the spike in Omicron cases has created trepidation for many parents.

items.title: How to Design a Home Gym That You’ll Actually Use
items.abstract: As the pandemic rages on, the safest place to work out is at home. Here’s how to create a personal gym you’ll want to spend time in.

items.title: As Omicron Infects Workers, Subway Service Suffers
items.abstract: With coronavirus cases surging in New York, about 21 percent of subway operators and conductors were absent this week, causing suspensions on three lines and changed schedules on others.
